body: Prospect Park Audubon Center Some see the arrival of the new year as an excuse to act like animals. And on Sunday at least one place will even encourage it. That's the Prospect Park Audubon Center, which will host family activities focused on the local wildlife, including the center's first game of animal charades. ''The goal of the program is to
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: AN urban farm off the East River. Artisanal food and crafts sold out of recycled shipping containers at the Dekalb Market. Smorgasburg and the Brooklyn Flea on the Williamsburg waterfront. They all share a hipper-than-thou aesthetic. They also share a pedigree: they were all set up to breathe some life into vacant lots. In an unlikely convergence
title: Send In the Food Trucks

body: WITH peanut butter fudge truffles, raspberry caramels and peppermint bark vying for her attention, Lorna Fontana, 12, had a difficult decision to make as she pressed her face to the glass counter at JoMart Chocolates like a kid, well, in a candy store. Her father, Michael Fontana, inhaled the sweet air of the confectionery, in the small Brooklyn
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | MADISON; A Family Tree Just Covered In Chocolate

body: She has come to be known for the brutal way in which she was killed: set ablaze inside an elevator, burned alive just feet from her apartment door. But in the modest six-floor building in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, where she died, Deloris Gillespie was often celebrated for how she lived, her considerable generosity and slight eccentricity on
title: Before a Brutal Death, a Reputation for Generosity and Eccentricity

author: A student at Borough of Manhattan Community College.
body: WHEN I was 14, my mother told me not to panic if a police officer stopped me. And she cautioned me to carry ID and never run away from the police or I could be shot. In the nine years since my mother gave me this advice, I have had numerous occasions to consider her wisdom. One evening in August of 2006, I was celebrating my 18th birthday with my
title: OPINION; Why Is the N.Y.P.D. After Me?

body: Alexander Garvin, natty in bowtie and jacket, watched commuters hustle through the gray, sunken concrete plaza at Citigroup Center on Lexington Avenue. Across 53rd Street, in the fading afternoon light, more New Yorkers ducked into a faceless subway kiosk on the triangular patch of wind-swept sidewalk -- ostensibly a second public plaza -- that
title: Treasuring Urban Oases

body: Twenty-five years ago my husband and I moved to Brooklyn, lured by the promise of more space than we could afford in Manhattan. We loved our big, sunny apartment and its proximity to Prospect Park, but if we wanted to eat in a restaurant that was not a pizzeria, or see a movie whose protagonist was not a superhero, we had to return to our old
title: The Academy

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Museum of Jewish Heritage: Writers' Discussion (Wednesday) The immigrant experience will be the conversation topic for two writers who have written extensively about their countries of origin -- Egypt for Lucette Lagnado, author of ''The Arrogant Years: One Girl's Search for Her Lost Youth, From Cairo to Brooklyn''
title: Spare Times

body: 'Untapped!' The young men at the New Victory Theater don't just dance with their bodies, they also dance with their voices. They're presenting ''Untapped!,'' a family show whose title reveals both its untrammeled energy and its freewheeling content. Expert hoofers, these fellows, based in Australia, extend tap into wild territories. With their
title: Spare Times: For Children

author: E-mail: dwyer@nytimes.com; Twitter: @jimdwyernyt
body: For the last few years, Richard Powell, a young man who saw himself as ''alone in the world,'' has marked Thanksgiving with a slice of pizza. The day after, he would go back to work at one of his jobs, at Burger King, the American Museum of Natural History or the Frick Collection. This year, though, he was up early Tuesday and helping prepare 800
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; At Rikers, Roasting Turkeys for a New Start

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Brooklyn Historical Society: 'Civil Rights in Brooklyn: Stories of Struggle and Protest' (Sunday) A discussion, with archivists and audience participation, on the impact in Brooklyn of the civil rights movement, in celebration of its 50th anniversary. 128 Pierrepont Street, near Clinton Street, Brooklyn Heights, (718)
title: Spare Times

body: The developer Bruce C. Ratner unveiled the design Thursday for what would be the world's tallest prefabricated steel structure, a 32-story residential building in Brooklyn at the corner of Flatbush Avenue and Dean Street in the $4.9 billion Atlantic Yards project. The 350-unit building would use varying rectangular shapes, colors and glass to break
title: CITY ROOM; A Design for Atlantic Yards' Prefab Tower

body: If, by some typically improbable turn of events, Homer Simpson were to unearth from his backyard an old chest containing a chess set from medieval times, what would the pieces look like? Chances are they would resemble the lovable little contestants beautifully carved from walrus tusks by anonymous artisans in the famous cache known as the Lewis
title: ART REVIEW; Medieval Foes With Whimsy

body: WHEN I visit a rural area, which I do only with great reluctance, there is often someone there urging me to awake before dawn with flashlight and steaming thermos, as if for a whale watch, and visit the local flea market. Though I love old things, this sense of urgency has never really resonated. Surely all the choicest tchotchkes and gewgaws won't
title: CRITICAL SHOPPER; A Tidy Flea, But What To Buy?

title: The Listings

body: COHEN--Abraham. Beloved husband of the late Paula. Loving father of Jonathan (Rita), and Kenneth (Barbara). Cherished grandfather or Meryl (Joseph), Jacqueline (Jon), Jared, Marc and Suzanne. Adoring great-grandfather of Dylan and Hayley. Devoted brother of Helen and the late Augusta, Etta, Irene, Pearl, and Rose. Dear uncle. Services today 1pm at
title: Paid Notice: Deaths COHEN, ABRAHAM

body: Inside a small, colorful shop in Brooklyn, Minnie Mouse is five feet tall and made entirely of balloons. This incarnation of the Disney character was the creation of Ianthe Cupid, who took pride in putting the finishing touches on it recently for the store's street display. ''I like when people see me create a sculpture with the balloons,'' said
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; After a Bad Accident, Finding Resilience in Balloons

body: A SALVAGED shipping container may seem an unpromising showcase for cutting-edge style. But not to Hekima Hapa (bottom left), who set up shop in one of the rectangular spaces scattered throughout the Dekalb Market in Brooklyn on Saturday. She deftly exploited her cramped quarters as an intimate backdrop for her African-themed, Brooklyn-sewn designs.
title: LIFE IS A RUNWAY; African Style Glows in Brooklyn

body: FINDING a home with room for a family can be hard enough in New York City. But when Barden and Catherine Prisant decided to sell their house in the East Village because a tall building was to go up next to their beloved backyard, their challenge grew by several degrees of difficulty. In addition to uprooting their 8-year-old daughter, the move
title: LIVING IN | PROSPECT PARK SOUTH, BROOKLYN; Houses Are Few, but Not Far Between

body: IT didn't take long for Sarbjit Singh to decide where to buy an apartment. Mr. Singh, who is known as Sab, had been living in Chelsea in a one-bedroom rental and working in the field of market research. A year ago, he was hired as an assistant professor of sports management at Farmingdale State College in Long Island. He wanted to buy a place, and
title: THE HUNT; Room for One and Occasionally More

body: WHEN she and her husband moved out in 1980, Kathy LaPolla DeStefano was not at all happy with Williamsburg, Brooklyn. ''The neighborhood was starting to go down the toilet, honestly,'' Ms. DeStefano, 56, an elementary school teacher, said over the telephone from her home in Coconut Creek, Fla. ''There was a lot of drugs and crime. It was an unsafe
title: On Facebook, Neighborhoods as They Once Were

body: A video that the police released this week of a shooting in Brooklyn shows the exacting care with which a group of criminals can handle a deadly weapon. Before Tyquan Sewall, 18, was shot in daylight hours on Tuesday outside a McDonald's in Flatbush, the gun that struck him down was passed from hand to hand to hand until it was pointed at Mr.
title: On Video, an Intricate Relay Of a Gun Before a Shooting

body: LOUIS SAVARESE, the son and grandson of butchers, was raised to know the difference between a rib-eye roast and a cross-rib roast, but he is the first in his family to appreciate the finer points of cow hooves and chicken feet. The Savarese family has run Michael's Prime Meats on Nostrand Avenue in Flatbush, Brooklyn, since 1931. As the
title: Staying Put In a City of Change

body: Sure, you could have gotten a haircut at the Phenomenon Barber Shop in Brooklyn in the early morning hours of Labor Day, but that was just one of any number of reasons to have stopped by. It was also a place to dance, to relax, to hang out with friends and -- regrettably, in hindsight -- to use the restroom after a few drinks. One thing led to
title: CRIME SCENE; A $1 Restroom Fee, It Turned Out, Came at a Cost

body: ''I SAW four people out on the road the other day,'' Roland Brown, a recent transplant to Cambria Heights in southeastern Queens, joked the other day about his new neighborhood. ''It was like rush hour.'' He might have been exaggerating. But he was not complaining. Quiet but not sleepy, manicured but not pretentious, Cambria Heights has long been a
title: LIVING IN | CAMBRIA HEIGHTS, QUEENS; Safe and Sound, Sweet and Spacious

body: IT'S a challenge for restaurants to offer exciting lists of expensive or even moderately expensive wines. It's a far greater challenge for restaurants to offer a wide selection of captivating, inexpensive wines. It requires creativity, thoughtfulness and dedication to gather wines that may not return as big a profit as the more expensive choices on
title: THE POUR; Restaurant Bottles From the Bottom Up

body: FOR its first retail endeavor, the Brooklyn design incubator 3rd Ward thought inside the box -- specifically, a salvaged shipping container. Shopbox, as they're calling it, opened Aug. 26 at the Dekalb Market in Downtown Brooklyn, where all of its neighbors are also housed in repurposed storage units. Painted a can't-miss green, with prominent
title: Unwrapped

body: It took OTB a long time to be born. And it is taking a long time to die. Make no mistake: the 50 or so Off-Track Betting Corporation parlors across the city have been closed since December. But very few of the spaces have found new tenants -- not in this economy, and not in their condition. So OTB lives on in ghostly apparition. The corner parlor
title: The Ghosts Of Wagers Past Linger On Across the City

body: WOLINTZ--Arthur Harry Dr. FACS, FACP. A man of exceptional character, integrity, intelligence, affection, and caring, passed away on August 22, 2011, in the presence of his devoted wife and adoring daughters. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he graduated Summa Cum Laude from SUNY, Downstate Medical Center in 1962, and was inducted into the Alpha Omega
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WOLINTZ, ARTHUR HARRY DR

body: WENDY AND THE LOST BOYS The Uncommon Life of Wendy Wasserstein By Julie Salamon Illustrated. 460 pages. The Penguin Press. $29.95. title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; And Now, Wendy Gets Her Chronicles

body: Many readers had strong reactions to last week's Metropolitan cover article by Peter Applebome, ''Williamsburg on the Hudson.'' Additionally, they took issue with the comparisons drawn between various Hudson Valley
title: READER COMMENTS; On the Hudson, Not Everyone Sees Williamsburg

An urban oasis designed today is very different from one designed in the days of Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux; you need only look at
title: Spare Times

title: ABUSED AND USED; Reaping Millions From Medicaid In Nonprofit Care for Disabled

Vital Theater Company has revived its musical adaptation of the books by Katharine Holabird and Helen Craig and the PBS series ''Angelina Ballerina the Next Steps.'' The show, by Susan DiLallo
title: Spare Times

body: I HAD never been so grateful to see a banana. Peeled and skewered, just plucked from the freezer, it was nearly smoking from the cold. It was then plunged into molten chocolate, sprinkled with sea salt and slowly twirled under a shower of crushed almonds. Made to order at Nana's, a stand found Saturdays at Smorgasburg in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, it
title: $25 AND UNDER; Quick! Before Summer Melts Away

body: By Saturday, 22 shipping containers in an array of colors will be in place for the opening of Dekalb Market, a collection of food, clothing and other retailers in downtown Brooklyn that will be open year-round. Ten food vendors have signed one-year leases for the 160-square-foot containers, some open on the long side with a counter and others open
title: FOOD STUFF; A Brooklyn Market With Vendors in Colorful Containers

body: Steel beams arc high into the Brooklyn sky, flanked by five cranes that rise from a deep, divisive hole in the ground. Sections of prefabricated concrete seat platforms and concourses -- the guts of every sports arena since Roman times -- are now in place. Trucks rumble through the hot, dusty corner of the 22-acre site known as Atlantic Yards.
title: An Arena Rises at Last, But Protests Carry On

body: It was only seven blocks. The boy had begged and his parents had said yes, he could walk part of the way home from day camp by himself. Together they had memorized the route. They had practiced a dry run together. But little Leiby Kletzky, 8, got lost. And Monday, his first taste of doing the grown-up thing, of walking alone through Borough Park,
title: 7 Blocks to Walk, Brooklyn Boy Never Got Home

body: When day broke on Wednesday in Borough Park, Brooklyn, the swarms of volunteers went home defeated, and the detritus of a frantic 36-hour search for a missing boy lay strewn by the curb. There were plastic water jugs, napkins and fliers outside the brick apartment building where Leiby Kletzky and his family lived on 15th Avenue, in the heart of the
title: After Coming Together for a Frantic Search, a Community Is Left Reeling

title: CURRENTS | DEALS; Sales at Gus* Modern, Steuben and More

body: Opening BETTO Jason Denton is taking a bite out of Brooklyn with this latest venture featuring bruschette, similar to but softer than his signature crostini, along with small plates for sharing, a few pastas and a frequently changing selections of ''furred, feathered and fish'' from small producers, mainly roasted and served for one or more.
title: Off the Menu

body: New York City pet shop ownership has its challenges: Pushy customers. Yapping pooches. And, it seems, drunken puppy purchasing. On Tuesday, the news Web site DNAinfo.com reported that two Greenwich Village pet shops had policies barring visibly intoxicated patrons from buying, playing with, or even cradling puppies. It turns out that the phenomenon
title: CITY ROOM; A United Front Against Drunken Puppy-Shopping

body: PIRATES OF THE HUDSON Forget the pirates of the Caribbean. In honor of this patriotic weekend, why not celebrate plundering and profiteering that took place closer to home? That idea has inspired Pirates of the Hudson: The Siege of Sleepy Hollow, a new festival at Philipsburg Manor, the restored Westchester County estate once owned by Frederick
title: Spare Times

body: Talk about the reverse of not in my backyard! You'd never know it from the looks of the swimming pool, back porches, patios, makeshift garage, basketball hoop, parking lot for five cars and other suburban amenities squatting in the middle of a square block in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, but they occupy a 20-foot-wide corridor that is officially a
title: Forgotten Railroad's Land Makes a Great Back Porch

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Bartow-Pell Mansion Museum: 19th-century baseball (Saturday) A game of old-fashioned baseball, played according to 19th-century rules and in period costumes by the New York Mutuals and the Mineola Washingtons, is scheduled for 1 p.m. There will also be a demonstration of rounders, a precursor to baseball, and house
title: Spare Times

body: When Mildred Furiya moved to a 19th-century town house on State Street in Brooklyn from a cramped walkup in Greenwich Village in 1967, a boarding house known for prostitution stood across a barren street, groups of unemployed men hung out on the corner and the Brooklyn House of Detention was a defining presence a block away. Standing in the garden
title: THE APPRAISAL; Her $16,000 Town House, Now Available for Just $1.879 Million More

body: Beachgoers in bathing suits and the patter of residents speaking Russian: Brighton Beach on a hazy Friday in June. But there were also packs of police officers, some in uniform and some in plain clothes; a pile of discarded crime scene tape; several patrol cars; and a mobile watch tower, obvious clues that something had happened there.
title: A Family Mourns as Bathers Return to a Beach

body: Like the Owen Wilson character in Woody Allen's ''Midnight in Paris,'' Avery Johnson goes back in time by night whenever he flips on the N.B.A. finals and watches the team he almost won a championship with five years ago. ''It eats at you and it fuels you,'' Johnson said, recalling how his Dallas Mavericks melted down with a 2-0 series edge and a
title: ON BASKETBALL; Nets' Dreams Under Construction

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Bartow-Pell Mansion Museum (Friday) The Primavera Consort will play music of the Baroque period, with works by Vivaldi, Telemann, Handel and Bach; at 7 p.m. Reservations are requested: (718) 885-1461. 895 Shore Road North, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx , bartowpellmansionmuseum.org; $8, $5 for 65+ and students, and free
title: Spare Times

body: Joo Han, the son of Korean immigrants, runs a Manhattan produce store that looks much as it did when his parents opened it a generation ago, working endless hours to forge a new life, banana by banana, milk carton by milk carton. But the shop that paved his parents' path to the middle class can barely cover the rent today. Mr. Han is thinking of
title: A New York Staple for Decades, Korean Grocers Are Dwindling

body: LEVITT--Mitzi. On May 28. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Loving and proud mother of Michael and the late Stacy. Mitzi leaves behind Maria, devoted friend and family member. A School secretary at the Rabbi Harry Halpern Day School of East Midwood Jewish Center. She was a supporter of charities and a treasured friend to many. Services Tuesday,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths LEVITT, MITZI

body: GREAT ADAPTATIONS For the under-18 crowd summer movies usually mean big aliens, big guns and even bigger explosions. But the creators of a new film series at the Museum of the Moving Image have been deliberately thinking small, choosing works rooted not in the ever-expanding digital world but in the old-fashioned printed page. Called Great
title: Spare Times

body: WHEN 1 of a Find, a high-end vintage clothing store, arrived on Lincoln Place in Park Slope, Brooklyn, during the spring of 2008, it was greeted with bland indifference. This is, after all, quite possibly the least chic neighborhood in New York City: a place where the closest thing to a club scene is cargo pants-clad, nose-pierced damsels gamboling
title: CRITICAL SHOPPER; Not So New, But Not Forgotten

author: E-mail: powellm@nytimes.com
body: Poor Michael Bloomberg. He possesses the third term he so desired and yet he seems not to know what to do with it. Several of our mayor's grander dreams -- congestion pricing, a West Side stadium, his Park Avenue schools chancellor -- have turned to dross, even as his ''Say what?'' moments pile up. In the past week, he gave a rhetorical back of his
title: GOTHAM; Despair? None Bloomberg Seems to See

title: Spare Times

This production, directed by Stephen Michael Rondel for the New Acting Company, brims with
title: Spare Times

body: Greenwich Village, May 1 Seven residences, ranging from a 19th-century townhouse where Emily Post once lived to a 350-square-foot apartment, will be open from 1 to 5:30 p.m. for the 13th annual event to benefit the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation. The tour will also include an Italianate home with an elaborately paneled entrance
title: New York City Home and Garden Tours

body: ''PARDON me,'' said CÃ©sar Ramirez. Thus begins a meal at one of the more extraordinary restaurants in New York City. Mr. Ramirez is the chef at the Chef's Table at Brooklyn Fare, on Schermerhorn Street in downtown Brooklyn. He stood like a ship's captain in front of the immense Molteni stove that is the centerpiece of his kitchen, the hearth
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; 20 Courses, Bite by Bite

body: ON the north side of Prospect Heights in northwestern Brooklyn, construction workers are busy building the Barclays Center, the future home of the New Jersey Nets. On the neighborhood's south side sit several of the borough's most venerable cultural institutions and attractions. And in between is an evolving neighborhood that is also a blend of the
title: LIVING IN | PROSPECT HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; Tucked Between Past and Future

title: Spare Times

body: With the police closing in, Luis Zeledon ducked into a closet, recognizing that his hideout in Queens had somehow been exposed. But for all Mr. Zeledon's evasiveness, the key to his arrest on murder charges in 2009 came days before the killing even occurred -- as he was driving his car. The Police Department's growing web of license-plate-reading
title: Camera Scans Of Car Plates Are Reshaping Police Inquiries

body: FOR New Yorkers drawn to old houses and apartments, the reminders that they are hardly the first to inhabit their rooms can be thrilling. If those people had their way, no one would ever empty a cellar or clear out an attic. ''It's the dream of someone who buys an old house to find things other owners had left behind,'' said Chris Kreussling, a
title: Message From A Stranger

body: Around Town Museums and Sites American Museum of Natural History (Monday) ''A Hitchhiker's Guide to Habitable Planets in Our Galaxy'' is a lecture by Linda Elkins-Tanton, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, on what is known about planetary formation; part of Hayden Planetarium's ''Frontiers in Astrophysics'' lecture series.
title: Spare Times

body: LET'S get this out of the way: The golf courses in New York City will never be confused with Pebble Beach, Bethpage Black or any of America's great public courses. If you want a four-and-a-half-hour round, meticulously manicured greens or even an unfailingly polite playing partner, consider going elsewhere. But if you appreciate the idea of hauling
title: Fairways Where Golf Becomes The City Game

body: 'REVOLTING RHYMES' Any poetry that includes the lines ''In the kitchen, peeling spuds,/Cinderella heard the thuds/Of bouncing heads upon the floor'' might justifiably be called revolting. But severed heads aside, this and other children's verses by Roald Dahl are revolting in another way. They strike a rebellious blow against the prettified world
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: By the time Kofi Owusu pulled his yellow cab up to the front of an East Village apartment building early one December morning in 2008, the passenger in the back seat had already vomited twice -- once inside the taxi, he said in court on Tuesday. The passenger, a 27-year-old woman, asked for help getting out of the car. Mr. Owusu told her he could
title: Witnesses in Police Rape Trial Outline Evening of Drinking

body: A police officer accused of raping a woman in her East Village apartment while on duty in December 2008 built a rapport with the woman during a discussion of alcoholism and had physical contact with her, but they did not have sex, his lawyer argued in court on Monday. In opening statements in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, lawyers laid out their
title: In Rape Case, Court Is Told Officer's Act Was Not Sex

body: Three guests at a baby shower in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, were shot after trying to chase down two men who had tried to rob another guest, a witness and the police said Sunday. What began as a joyous occasion at a banquet hall on Saturday night turned violent after one of the guests reported that two men had accosted him while he stood outside,
title: 3 Partygoers Injured in Shooting Outside Brooklyn Banquet Hall

body: IN honor of President's Day last month, Deb Winsor, a carpenter with a workshop in Brooklyn, led a crew in the construction of an 8-foot-wide model of the White House, complete with north and south porticos and two dozen hand-painted windows. After reviewing the plans with the workers, Ms. Winsor, 50, supervised them as they laid out two-by-fours
title: Big Tools For Little Hands

body: Around Town Museums and Sites Brooklyn Historical Society (Saturday and Sunday) A discussion about the life and career of the Brooklyn Dodgers right fielder Carl Furillo, with Ted Reed, author of ''Carl Furillo: Brooklyn Dodgers All-Star''; Judith Testa, author of ''Sal Maglie: Baseball's Demon Barber''; and Carl Furillo Jr.; Saturday at 2 p.m. The

body: Updated 9:00 p.m. | State Senator Kevin S. Parker, who faced as much as two years in prison for his role in attacking a staff photographer from The New York Post, was sentenced on Monday to three years' probation. Prosecutors had sought to put Mr. Parker behind bars for 30 days, followed by 30 days of supervised release. A lawyer for Mr. Parker,
title: Probation for State Senator in Attack on Photographer

body: EVEN in a city that celebrates unbridled ostentation, the sprawling estate at 139 Bassett Avenue in the seaside enclave of Mill Basin, Brooklyn, seems to redefine conspicuous consumption. The front yard is a gaudy stab at Versailles, with four-foot obelisks at each corner of the driveway, intricately tiled fountains and a series of steel sculptures
title: A Senator's Shadow Family

body: I TOOK my first close look at the Juke, Nissan's new funhouse-mirror crossover, a few weeks before my 40th birthday. The truth quickly settled in: man, you are way too old for this car. It was clear right away whom the Juke was meant for. I could just picture him in his American Apparel hoodie, sipping a latte from his favorite locally owned coffee
title: BEHIND THE WHEEL | 2011 NISSAN JUKE; A Design So Far Out It Just Might Be In

body: The Atlantic Yards project began with much fanfare in December 2003, when the developer Bruce C. Ratner unveiled his plans at a pep rally at Brooklyn Borough Hall: an exotic basketball arena and a sprawling residential development that would provide affordable housing, jobs and community development. The $4.9 billion project took a battering during
title: Federal Case and Modular Building Plan Bring New Attention to Atlantic Yards Project

body: Two trash cans flank the white-brick gateposts on Flatbush Avenue, with ''Long Island University'' hanging atop a shuttered gate and ''Brooklyn'' and ''Center'' on each side, a remnant of the campus's past. No geographic reminder is necessary these days with buses rumbling, sirens wailing and straphangers rushing out of the nearby DeKalb subway
title: It May Be News to Brooklyn, but Basketball's Spotlight Is on One of Its Own

body: In a bid to cut costs at his star-crossed Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn, the developer Bruce C. Ratner is pursuing plans to erect the world's tallest prefabricated steel structure, a 34-story tower that would fulfill his obligation to start building affordable housing at the site. The prefabricated, or modular, method he would use, which is
title: Atlantic Yards Plans to Build Tallest Prefab

body: Walter Zacharius, who rode the passion-swollen wave of romance fiction in the early 1980s to build the Kensington Publishing Corporation into a leading purveyor of bodice-rippers and other romance genres, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87. The cause was pancreatic cancer, his son, Steven, said. Mr. Zacharius emerged from the
title: Walter Zacharius, 87, Romance Publisher

body: Florence Cozzolino remembers the man who used to live down the street from her at 178 Marine Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. She and other children from the neighborhood would gather outside his house, waiting for him to return home so they could ask for his autograph. Her neighbor was not an actor. He was another sort of Brooklyn celebrity: He was
title: Remembering When Players Also Were Neighbors

body: ''Willie, Mickey and the Duke,'' the Terry Cashman song about three center fielders, defined New York baseball in the '50s. For old times' sake, Willie Mays returned recently to the Harlem streets above the old Polo Grounds where he made that over-the-shoulder catch for the Giants in the 1954 World Series, but Mickey Mantle is mentioned mostly as a
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Duke of Flatbush, A Brooklyn Icon

body: YOSWEIN--Leonard E. Family, friends, and co-workers mourn the death of Hon. Leonard E. Yoswein, born September 8, 1920 in Manhattan. After a long and distinguished life of public service, he died on February 25, 2011. Judge Yoswein's career began at age 16 when he managed father Adolph Yoswein's tuxedo rental shop after his father was injured. He
title: Paid Notice: Deaths YOSWEIN, LEONARD E

title: Spare Times

body: The cigarettes Audrey Silk used to smoke -- Parliament Lights -- are made at a factory in Richmond, Va. The cigarettes she smokes these days are made and grown in Brooklyn, at her house. Ms. Silk's backyard is home to raspberry and rose bushes, geraniums, impatiens and 100 tobacco plants in gardening buckets near her wooden deck. Inside her house,
title: Now in Brooklyn, Homegrown Tobacco: Local, Rebellious And Tax Free

body: Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. title: The Listings

body: Firefighters were briefly delayed in putting out a fire in Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Saturday night because an engine that had been sent to the blaze was already at another emergency, attending to a police officer who had accidentally shot himself in the leg, the Fire Department said Monday. The fire eventually took the life of a 64-year-old woman
title: Error Delayed Fire Dept. In Fatal Brooklyn Blaze

body: A retired guidance counselor was killed and more than 100 residents were forced to flee into the chill of a winter night when a wind-whipped fire raced through a seven-story apartment building in Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Saturday evening. Roughly 200 firefighters struggled in the dark for seven hours -- from dinnertime Saturday to early Sunday -- to
title: Brooklyn Woman Dies As Blaze Displaces 100

title: Spare Times

body: Flowers were piled at the foot of the twin wooden coffins lined up end to end on the second floor of a Brooklyn funeral home on Tuesday morning: bouquets of all white for the mother, Anna Bulchenko, 56, and white-and-pink arrangements for her 20-year-old daughter, Yelena. Wandering between them, clutching a tissue and swaying in anguish, was
title: At Funeral, Police Regret They Couldn't Stop Killer

body: Abdul Haye, the self-styled Colonel Sanders of New York's Afghan community, has declared a fried chicken war. He has armed himself with an unwritten secret recipe that he claims allows him to fry the best bird in town. His main weapon, he says, is ownership of the trademark for the Kennedy Fried Chicken brand, which has spawned hundreds of
title: A Chicken War in New York, Where Afghans Rule the Roost

body: THE Brooklyn Cruise Terminal on the Buttermilk Channel has picturesque views even when the Queen Mary 2, which docks there regularly, is at sea. There is verdant Governor's Island across the water and, behind it , the heaving, jagged rise of Manhattan. To the north are the great bridges of the East River. To the west, the Statue of Liberty. And to
title: 36 HOURS; Brooklyn

title: Spare Times

body: Q.Can you explain why some Metro-North train cars have two sets of doors and some have three? And why are the middle doors kept closed on many runs? A. All 813 of Metro-North's electric-train cars have two sets of doors, plus the connecting doors at each end, said Marjorie Anders, a Metro-North spokeswoman. Of the roughly 200 cars that are hauled
title: F.Y.I.; Three-Door Commuting

body: Opening EMBER ROOM No longer associated with Kittichai in SoHo, Ian Chalermkittichai has gone back to using his full surname. Now he has teamed with Todd English to create Asian-inflected barbecue in a space sheathed in dark reclaimed boards, some looking as if they came from a wood pile out back. A special oven is the centerpiece between the bar
title: Off the Menu

body: Leo Martinez spent a backache-inducing 40 minutes on Thursday clearing 19 inches of snow from the roof and windows of his S.U.V., in the winter wonderland that was East Tremont in the Bronx. It was hard work, but it was costing him, too: He had to pay the two men helping him dig out his car $10 each. ''My baby is sick at home, and we're trying to
title: How Bad Is the Snow? Depends Where You Live

body: 'VELMA GRATCH & THE WAY COOL BUTTERFLY' Being the youngest child often has disadvantages, including hand-me-downs, distracted parents and a dearth of baby pictures in the family album (while Mom and Dad have enough of their firstborn to fill a feature-length documentary). But for Velma Gratch the biggest problem is her sisters' reputations. They're
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: When Al Attara bought a former bank on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn 32 years ago for under $250,000, he envisioned it as a complex in which artists, architects and furniture designers would work side by side and share ownership of the 45,000-square-foot space. But Mr. Attara's plans languished, in part because the bank building was declared part of
title: SQUARE FEET; On Flatbush Avenue, Seven Stories Chock-Full of Ideas

body: A 14-year-old boy and two men were shot to death in three separate attacks within four hours in the city on Monday afternoon, the police said. The police said the 14-year-old boy was fatally shot about 6 p.m. after a dispute with three men who approached him at East 219th Street and White Plains Road in the Bronx. The victim was found on the street
title: 3 Fatally Shot in Separate Attacks Within 4 Hours

body: THE view north across the East River from a high floor at Oro, a new 40-story condominium tower at 306 Gold Street in Downtown Brooklyn, is eye-popping, a panorama of clouds, bridges, water and skyscrapers in Manhattan. But gazing to the south and west from the same perch reveals a more traditional Brooklyn landscape: here a cluster of bank
title: Suddenly, A Brooklyn Skyline

body: OPENINGS QUEEN OF E.VIL, a label best known for its graphic T-shirts, including its horoscope series ($80) and colorful cashmere sweaters ($250), has opened its first boutique, Bond 666. The NoHo store will have art installations in the soaring 18-foot-high space. The brand was started by Aimee David in 1999 and has done collaborations with Max
title: Scouting Report
